text: Dégustée dans un verre Mille et une bières,belle robe brune opaque surmontée dune mousse de couleur crème assez persistante avec une bonne carbonatation.Le nez nous offre des arômes de chocolat,fruits noirs avec des notes vineuses.La bouche nous amène sur des saveurs à limage du nez avec un agréable velouté mêlé à une fine amertume qui se prolonge en finale nous laissant sur une sensation de légèreté et de complexité.Un ensemble très harmonieux nous donnant envie dy retourner!

Dégustée dans un verre Mille et une bières.
Température de début 9 à 10°.
Superbe robe opaque de couleur ébène surmontée dune mousse crème à grosses bulles et plutôt persistante; bonne carbonatation.
Nez très plaisant et subtil mêlant les arômes de torréfaction et les senteurs fruitées et houblonnées.
Le goût est riche et complexe: café, fruits noirs dans un équilibre idéal; en deuxième bouche dautres saveurs de chocolat se révèlent discrètement et une agréable amertume se profile.
La finale est longue, légèrement astringente et sans la moindre lourdeur.
Délicieuse comme un Irish blues de Rory Gallagher!

330ml bottle of Antwerpen Stout, from Tesco, Warfield. An opaque mahogany coloured pour with an amber glint and a loose beige head; rich aroma of mollasses with a touch of spice; taste of burnt sugar with some coffee and licorice; and a cinder toffee finish. rather good.

Great stout but lacks it's own unique flavor. Body is not strong but we'll balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI. Almost black brown. Bright hop aroma, deep cocoa. Smooth somewhat boozy, prune and raisin finish.

330ml Antwerpen from Tesco - Solid black body, thick tan head. Looks great. Nose is burnt grains and nuts, lots of coffee grinds, bit of smoke and liquorice. Taste is fine, not as powerful as expected, a little muted version of all the aroma notes. Good mouthfeel though, big and syrupy. ABV well masked.

"Antwerpen Stout" Bottle at home, all alone. Roasty, fruity nose. Notes of cherry, raisin, cinnamon, cereal, strawberry. Full bodied and chewy. Roasted malts, wood, berry jam, molasses, vegemite notes. Long complex finish, with sweet woody flavors developing.

This was labeled "Antwerpen Stout". NIce roasted malt aroma. Dark brown body with a ruddy tinge and thick tan head. Cocoa, dark chocolate and raisins in the taste. Fuller bodied than regular Guinness and a definite alcohol bite. Still has some of the original Guinness flavor with more roasted notes and dark fruit. Very nice heavy stout.
UPDATED: MAY 17, 2017 Achetée au Hyper U de Sierentz. Bière noire à la mousse beige. Nez caramélisé, et whisky. En bouche elle est ronde, on retrouve le caramel et le malt. Très bonne bière.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick brown foam residing like ice cream. Scent is medium notes of caramel malt and brown sugar. Taste is consistent with light sour properties. Finish is dense and smooth like an ale of much higher ABV. Lingering notes of proper fresh malt. Great.

Bottle at home picked up from Tesco. As "Guinness Antwerpen". Surprised i hadnt ticked this before. A dark caramel brown coloured pour with a rocky mid tan head that fades. Aroma holds some sweet malt loaf, blackberry, jam, vanilla. Little meaty on the nose. Flavour is composed of sweet tangy brown malts, brown sugars liquorice and treacle, apple and dark berries, earth. Palate is medium bodied, frothy carbonation medium sweet with a tang in the finish. Archetypal for the style.
Bottle 33cl. Pours a dark beer with long lasting beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Full body, oily with soft carbonation. Taste is roasted malt, bitter, hops and caramel. 05/17

This bottled brew from a bottle shop was served at a cool temperature and poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to medium sized brown colored bubbles that were very long lasting and left behind a strongly carbonated body opaque black brown colored body and a thick foamy lacing. The weak aroma was dark malt. The thick mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish with a medium mild roasted malt aftertaste. The thick flavor contained notes of roasted malt brown malt and dark malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

Bottle, 330ml, as Guinness Antwerpen Stout. A deep black colour with a large frothy brown head. Aroma of dough, sweet malt, roasted barley. Flavour is deeply malty with coffee and some barley notes. Berries in the finish along with a little alcohol burn. High carbonation. Very tasty.

Bottle from Tesco online, Antwerpen Stout. Cunning rebranding! Dark black colour, off white foam. For me way overcarbonated for the style, almost fizzy. Roasty, slightly boozy, but something in there feels rather sweet maybe slightly underfermented. Its ok but Id have liked it drier, more bitter, more roasty and less fizzy.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2017 Butelka 330ml. Pite jako Antwerpen Stout. Ciemny ,prawie czarny kolor. Piana brazowa ,natychmiast zanika. Aromat raczej subtelny i malo intensywny z owocami na pierwszym planie i czekolada,kawa i slodami w tle. Dosc duza karbonacja jak na stouta. W smaku dosc slodkie z owocowa nuta dobrze zbalansowana przez kawe i czekolade. Rodzynki wanilia sliwki i czarna porzeczka.Bardzo pijalne lecz zapach troche rozczarowuje. Na plus alkohol dobrze ukryty.
Bottle at home, 29th April 17. Pours black, white head. Aroma is liquorice, sharp, vineous, dark chocolate. Taste is liquorice, roasted malts, dark chocolate. Liked it

330ml bottle. As Antwerpen Stout. Pours jet black with a tan head. Nose is dark fruits, roasted malt, toasted brown bread,dark chocolate and raisin. Medium carbonation and a medium thick mouth feel. Taste is raisin, prune, roasted malt, bitter chocolate,vanilla,oak wood and a slight alcohol burn. Bitter finish. Awesome, still prefer the foreign extra though !
Bottle from Tesco as Antwerpen stout. Pours almost black, beige head. Nose is sweet dark malts, cocoa, light liquorice. Tastes sweet malty, chocolate, faint coffee. Quite sweet, ok if a bit boring.
Fabulous. Like normal Guinness but much much better. Such deep roasted malted chocolate flavours. A very smooth mouth feel, very much worth a try!

Jet black with medium frothy caramel foam. Aromas of light warming booze, cocoa and chocolate malts. As well as, cream, and soft spice liqueur. Palate, full body, thick creamy texture leaving soothing roasted hazelnut finish. Taste, smooth and light sweet with notes of cocoa, cream and chocolate as well as touch of liqueur with that hint of walnut skin bitterness followed by nut oils. Overall, very nice, soft and silky, almost sensual beer, really nice to slowly enjoy it.
Bottle (as Antwerpen Stout ) from Tescos. Black pour with a lasting beige head. Raisin, coffee, dark chocolate and light smoke aroma. Vanilla, toffee, caramel and coffee flavour. Not bad.
Why have the Belgians been having the best stuff for years its not like they have a shortage of good beers over there.! Dark sweet sugary malt balanced with dark roast and a warming alcohol.

Pours with a good amount of the typical Guinness foam. Color is again typical Guiness, almost pitch black. Aroma is fruity and burnt and has lighter fruits such as raspberry as well as a selection of dark fruits such as plum and apricot. Some coffee and roasted malt as well. Palate is fairly well balanced and the carbonation is ok for the style. Taste is burnt and fairly bitter with strong burnt overall characteristic. Theres also a rich malty and dried dark fruity overall taste. Its recognizable as a Guinness, although it has been some time I had a Guinness last time and for some reason this one tastes like a different Guinness (less sweet one and missing the body that Ive come to expect from Guinness). Perhaps the noticeable difference comes from the pub version being at a lower alc. %. I have to say that I prefer the lower alc. % version.

Birra dal colore nero. Schiuma fine e moderatamente persistente. 
Al naso sentori di malto, caffe e toffe. Al palato ritornano tutte le note già percepite allolfatto. Moderatamente carbonata, una buona birra, molto beverina per essere una stout.

Bottle (labeled as "Antwerpen Stout"). I wasnt expecting too much, so I was pleasantly surprised. This is chocolatey and smooth, with a deep, rich flavor that reminded me of a Baltic Porter. Theres an interesting raisin-ish sweetness in the middle that adds a bit of a Belgian dubbel taste as well. The mouthfeel is a bit thin and it ends a bit abruptly, but otherwise this is really quite a good stout.

Just a shade of light shows through the dark pour, the tan head leaves quickly. Nose is charred barley and chicory. Bittersweet. Middle is smokey malt, touch of expresso, some vanilla liquer, and mild hop bitterness. Finish shows a nice bittersweet depth.

330 ml bottle, bb 08.10.17.
Black body, with a big, creamy, lacing, beige head.
Dense aroma of dried fruits, caramel, chocolate, cocoa powder, vanilla, some coffee, some toast.
Tastes quite similar, but sweeter and a bit less rich than the nose
Medium, creamy mouthfeel, with an average carbonation.
Finishes quite cloying, moderate roasty, slightly dry, a bit toasty, with brown sugar, molasses, cocoa.

Nice one. The nose is really lovely, with diverse fruit and dark malt notes, has some Belgian twist. The taste is too sweet though for my taste, even getting a bit dull towards the finish. Overall still quaffable stuff, but I was expecting a bit more, not as good as their lovely Foreign Extra Stout in my opinion.
Totally decent. Quite full bodied, little carbonation. Sweet, malty, some chocolate. No real bitterness.

Botella 0,33L Color negro con espuma de color cafe, alta, fina, resistente, muy presentable. Aroma complicada, cafe, chocolate, pan, frutas secas, malta. Sabor cafe, chocolate,ciruela seca, malta.Una combinacion perfecta de dulzor suave y amargor, que se queda prolongado en postgusto en la boca.Viscosa,con cuerpo.

Bottle from Tesco, Cromwell Road, Earls Court, London. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top which doesnt hang around for long. Roasty, malty, chocolate aroma. Tastes roasty, malty, chocolate, some dark fruit, pretty sweet mind you. Pretty good stout but one bottle was quite enough.
Bottle. Nose is hazelnut syrup, latte, cream, coffee, chocolate. Nice. Taste is sweet, cheap chocolate, hazelnut, marshmallow, little coffee. Mouthfeel is sticky.

Bottle frae local Tesco. Pours very dark. Oily tan head. Aroma has an initial toasted hazlenut note. Roasted chocolate. Dried plums and raisins. Little heat from the booze. Taste is sweet with a fruity acidity. Berry notes. Very light balsamic tang. A little metallic. Also tannic. Light bitterness. More dried fruits on the finish. Port warmth. Medium-weight mouthfeel. Average carbonation. Mmmm.... not for me.

Deep brown-black with a roasty head. Interesting nose of milk sugar, mild roastiness, caramel, butterscotch/diacetyl, and some sour Belgian character. On the palate, the muted roastyness is overwhelmed by butterscotchy/diacetyl character. Some thin chocolate alcohol and raisin notes emerge on the finish.

Pours black with a medium beige head that recedes very slowly. The aroma is robust, with chocolate, caramel, raisin, cherry, and vanilla. The taste is dry with a minor, lingering sweetness. Its heavy in chocolate with a coffee compliment. There is a good degree of roasted malts, some raisin and caramel, and slight licorice. The aftertaste is long and is a roasted coffee. This is medium in body, has more of a creamy texture, and is softer in carbonation. This might be the best Guinness product that Ive found yet.

Bottle. Black with a tiny head. Aroma of butter, cake, cookies and butterscotch. Taste is chocolate, cookies, coffee, some hoppy bitterness and alcohol. Mouthfeel is rather thin. Its definitely quite good but I prefer the Foreign Extra Stout.

OTers of the Year tasting with Richthevillan. Bottle from Tesco, West Bromwich shared with Richthevillan. Black beer with small tan head. Aroma of dark malts, marzipan and light coffee. Taste is prune juice, roasted malts and toffee. Good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle during OTers of the year tasting session beer bottle via Tesco and Sarkynorthener cheers Martin; dark brown with a thin tan head, aroma has dark malts and chocolate, taste has sweet chocolate, along with some roast, hint of dark fruits.
Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma is of roasted malt and maybe a bit of dark fruit and chocolate . Taste is sort of fruity. Overall its a Guinness I like.

Bottle from Tescos labelled as Antwerp Stout. Pours opaque very dark brown to black with medium tan foam head which dissipates to thin. Nose is very nice. Rich roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel, dusty cocoa, black coffee, some dried fruit, prune, raisin, plum. Taste is fruity, plum, raisin, prune, fig, dark chocolate, roasted malt, burnt malts, black coffee, ruby fruits. Bit of butteriness in the finish. This is really nice. Possibly best Guinness Ive had.

Bottle, from Tesco (as Antwerpen Stout). Jet black, thin short lived beige head and gentle condition. Low fruity berry notes in the nose with some roasted barley. In the mouth it starts with a hint of sweetness, with a building bitter roasted note, some burnt toffee and a hint of liquorice. Finish has a little liquorice and some lingering bitterness.

Bottle from Tesco (1944 Antwerp Stout). Black body with a medium beige head. Faint lacing. Aroma of flat Coca-Cola and dirt. Flavour of red berries, roasted malt and nuts. Medium body with a smooth, frothy texture. Soft fizz. A solid beer.
Worcesthire sauce in cocoa somewhat beery in taste and moreso in aroma. Chocolate i guess and velvety without being heavy. Kinda cocoa puff like.
Bottle.Dark brown colour with medium beige headAroma is roasted and malty with flavor of caramel and burnt bread,good medium body and hint of chocolate and roasted malt smooth light finish.

17 March 2016: From Hipercor. In Teku glass. Watching True Detective 2x03. Much better than the more common Guinness Draught. That one I cant finish. This one Ive enjoyed. Addictive aroma and good taste and mouthfeel. Avg 4.2

 5 March 2017. In Ikeas pint glass. This is the only one guinness it has sense to exist.

Bottle. Pours a black body with a one inch foamy beige head. The nose is heavy roast and sweetness with coffee and burnt malt. The flavor is fairly different than the typical Foreign Export, its a little fruitier and theres a heavier burnt malt finish than the regular. It almost gets to a slightly rubbery quality on the finish actually. Medium to full bodied with fizzy active carbonation and a lingering finish. Meh, I think that I just prefer the standard version.

Just finishing up a bottle of this under the US Antwerp Stout label; this light-yet-heavy roasty stout pours an exceptionally pleasant red and brown accented black hue with an eggshell white head. Aroma is some dark chocolate malt, and also some tangy tartness reminiscent of a sweet balsamic vinegar, interesting. Flavor is a disappointingly understated roasted chocolate malt, some licorice, and a bit of spiced jaegermeister woodiness. Overall a nice flavor profile, just not enough flavor intensity. Somewhat creamy, but also fairly thin. Some subtle alcoholic acidity a la balsamic vinegar again, but not too boozy considering the ABV. Enjoyable and Im glad I tried it, but not something I would go out of my way for again.

From the 330 ml. bottle (US release) stamped L619OGF003. Deep a dark brown to black, heady pour. Looks excellent. The aroma is dark roasted malts, Guinness house yeast, sweet caramel, burnt bread, and a low to no hop profile. The body is light to medium and a little acidic. The taste has a lovely toasted roasted dark malt, Graham cracker, and milky character with a slight bitterness to finish.

Tap @ Hugos w friends/Mrs Schultz, Boilermaker & Hasselhoff. Appearance: clear black with good beige soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: caramel, coffee, light alcohol and chocolate. Palette: strong roasted malty aroma, light to average carbonation, medium to full body, average to notable sweetness, somewhat balanced by a medium bitterness, average to long duration and an oily texture. Overall: tasteful somewhat strong guiness version

330mL bottle, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma brings out toasted bready malt and a little roast. Flavour is along the same lines, followed by bready malt, English malt and and light sweetness. Nothing very deep and with a rather light palate. Its okay.

Bottle in Seattle. As Antwerpen stout. Creamy soft lace, dark brown stout body. Bitter grain, bitter chocolate and coffee nose. Deep rich body with some odd sour edges. Dusty yeast character. Deep bitter grain, reduced stout syrup. Odd bitter depths. Chicory, bitter greens. Oddly thin, vegetal. Some bright yeast character undermined by heavy bitterness. Interesting.

Sweet chocolate malty, some caramel notes, light toasted malty nuances, some dark dried fruit, nice smooth mouthfeel, easy drinking for the abv.

Aroma - coffee with a bit of alcohol, some warm chocolate, a bit of burn with some sourness, a bit of sweetness in the background. Taste - slightly sweetened diluted coffee, chocolate with milk and a bit of burn (roasted/burnt malt) in the background, quite a bit sweet and soured, a bit bitter and spicy in the final.

330ml bottle from the Old Fishing Shack Pub in Paphos. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is vanilla, sweet caramel, slight roastiness. Taste is milk chocolate, light coffee notes, raisins. Creamy mouthfeel. Better than the usual Guinness for sure.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2017 The Export version is better than the regular. More body. Some sweetness, but nicely dry without being bone dry. Charcoal, caramel, raisins, figs. Nice carbonisation.

Negra opaca con corona de espuma color beige de buena retención,  cierto encaje. En nariz aparecen notas a maltas tostadas, cacao y fenólica a clavo de olor. En boca, medio cuerpo y un carbónico ajustado, predomina más los sabores especiados que a maltas tostadas, ligeras notas a regaliz y chocolate negro en el retrogusto. Una stout fermentada con levadura belga, muy fenólico cargadita de alcohol y seca, para animar el trago.

Robe brune dense, mousse crémeuse beige. Nez élégant où lon retrouve à la fois des notes de malt torréfié, de café noir, de chocolat, de caramel sur une note lactée, pointe dépices douces. Bouche à lattaque à la fois tendue et concentrée, bulle acidulée, de la fraîcheur malgré la torréfaction, longue finale sur lamer du chocolat et du café. Un Stout très digeste et complexe.

Bottle, as Antwerpen. Pours black With large light beige head and lasting lacing.  Aroma is dark fruit, chocolate, caramel, woodsy. Taste is slightly sweet, dark fruit, raisin, hint of bitter tartness. Mouthful is heavy, smooth, carbonated.
Een geur van drop. Pikzwarte kleur. De smaak is zoals drop, absoluut mijn ding niet. Geen aanrader.
Near black with a tall beige head. Roasted malts, sour dark fruit background, chocolate, faint smoke. Medium body. Lingering tart and roasted malt. A very enjoyable stout. Labeled as Antwerpen Stout.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Inky black brew with two fingers of tan head, great head retention and lacing. Nice aroma of toasted grain, a little smoke, coffee, wood and caramel. Taste follows aroma. Surprisingly light and agile palate and lack of booziness. A really excellent twist on the Guinness stout Im familiar with.

Bottle, as "Antwerpen." Dark brown, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, lactic twang. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, minty hops. Medium bodied, well balanced. Nice.
Bottle. Near black with one finger head. Roasty malt, chocolate, dark fruit, smoke and some black licorice. Slight bitterness in the finish. Not bad.
lots of brown foam big head. aroma sweet cocoa barley a bit leather. tastes leather prunes old smoked wood. Great flavor. mild and smooth for 8%. seems sorta watery is the only downside. firm bitter.

Ar: Medium-intensity char and pineapple esters; light diacetyl and some tannins. Ap: Deep brown with red highlights, clear where light reveals highlights; medium-large tanned brown head with good retention, leaving an airy, fluffy cap of foam. T: Sweet burnt caramel and medium-low diacetyl; medium bitterness, herbal and very earthy; heavy roast, tar-like; phenolic smoke on the finish, with lingering bitterness and blackstrap molasses. P: Medium-full body with medium carbonation, medium-dry finish. O: Big stout with a fair level of complexity, including char, smoke, and dark caramel; some diacetyl, but not unbalancing in light of the style and yeast character; sweetness is nice, melding well with the dark malt, sugar, and fruit flavors.

11.2 ounce bottle. Pours a dark black with a three inch dark tan head. Taste is of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, coffee, grain and dark fruit. Similar aroma. Has a mostly full body. Overall, very good.

12 oz single bottle from Hy Vee Wine & Spirits - Muscatine. Deep, dark brown appearance with a lingering tan head. Aroma and flavor of bitter chocolate, toasted grain, light fruity esters and hints of coffee and roasted malt. OK.

Bottled as Antwerpen Stout. From Total Wine & More - West Richmond. $2.99. Pours nearly black with a small tan head. Nice aroma - raisins, chocolate, smoke, honey. Flavor is similar- raisins, chocolates, honey, light smoke, light coffee. Quite fucking tasty. Why isnt this the Guinness thats all over America? Lightly sweet finish...
Bottle. Very dark with tan head. Smells like good dark bread with honey. Flavor follows with some lemon. Lightly bitter.

As Guinness Antwerpen Stout. Aroma is black patent malt, cookie batter, oatmeal, basement, buttery suggestions of diacetyl that come across like milk sugar, but seems to blow off with time. Phenols develop into pepper, minerals, clay. Medium body and expansive carbonation give it a leanness that defies its strength. Lots of chewy cookie-caramel sugars with a lengthy and drying dusty / burnt bread finish that shows the hop bitterness well. The malt has some interesting angles but still seems incomplete, as little wafts of milk and clay / soil come and go. Its an easy drinker with the right frame of mind.

Pours dark black, amber, very slightly translucent with a huge, pillowy, tan head and an aroma of mild cinnamon, brown sugar, coffee and malt. Tastes of silky smooth malt with an ever so slight hop, anisette finish with very well hidden alcohol. Its very smooth and warming. Ireland!

Kolor ciemno brązowy, z rubinowymi refleksami. To co tworzy się na powierzchni piwa to ogromna czapa beżowej piany. Drobno pęcherzykowa, wysoka i trwała.
Aromat ciemnych, palonych słodów, nieco owocowy, ze śliwkami na pierwszym planie..
Smak: tutaj też nie ma zaskoczenia, paloność, karmel, ciemne owoce delikatnie kwaśne. Finisz goryczkowy o charakterze kawowym, wytrawny.
Nasycenie średnie.

Guinness has brought various versions of its Stout to America in the past years. I always look forward to trying them. Antwerpen label, darkest medium bodied Belgian stout with chocolate, coffee, smoke and moderate bitterness. No matter the name I really like this stout.

Had as Antwerpen Stout. Pours opaque coffee sable with a thick and fairly persistent tan head. Aroma presents yeasty, roast malt, and molasses tones. Flavor ups the roast malt and adds a smoky tone, while downplaying the yeast. Mouthfeel has firm body and some good fizz. Not quite as good as the original Guinness, but definitely drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2017 Also known as Antwepen stout.  Black with a quickly dissipating khaki head. Aroma is dark fruits and chocolate malts. Taste is roasted malts and sweet figs. Guinness stout with belgium sweetness.
Aroma is dark malts, dark fruit/raisins and liquor. The flavor is dark fruit/mild raisins, malts/dark malts and a liquor/mildly sweet finish.
11.2 ounce bottle. Label reads "Antwerpen Stout". Pours black with a nice tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and a bit of smoke. Good one.
Decent roasty stout, though I dont know what this does to earn a top 50 spot. Dark roast, bitter hops and light cocoa/caramel. Medium dry smooth body and finish.

Bottle - Sweet, dark and fruity malts. Raisin and plum. Jet black brown with a rich light brown head. Dark rich and sweet malts like the nose. Dark breads, fig and a sweet and light bitter finish. Nice.

F: huge, brownish, stable.
C: dark as a night, opaque.
A: roasted malt, saltiness, hint of chocolate, dark fruits, toast, spicy, cocoa.
T: malty, roasted malt, earthy, coffee, chocolate, light vanilla, dark fruits, liquorice, medium to full body, normal carbonation, yes also salty tones are there and no surprise there is 0,6 salt/100ml so in 0,5l can it´s 3g salt! But good balanced and tasty beer, enjoyed, 50cl can yes not only in bottle I checked it twice it´s this Belgian version, from Delhaize in Brussels.
33cl wmbossed bottle. This is not great stuff, huge savory yeast character, un dried tomato, cape gooseberry, just flavors I dont want in beer. Extreme yeast character.

Served from bottle into pint glass. 
Pours a 3" foamy tan head that drops very slowly with abundant lacing. Color is opaque black. Aroma of deeply roasted malt, coffee, and herbal hops. Mouthfeel is heavy and slightly astringent with a lingering finish. Flavors of dark roasted malt, smoked malt, peat, coffee, chocolate, with a lingering bitterness after the swallow. Another excellent offering from Guinness.

Bottle.

A- Dates, grapes, raisins, subtle red wine, chocolate, caramel.

A- Black color, black liquid, light brown head.

T- Roasty, subtle red wine, wood, dry cocoa, subtle smoke.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, roasty finish.

O- I really enjoyed this one. Had tons of those dark fruit notes on the nose that I tend to relate with in a foreign stout. Less of them on the palate as it was more of a woodsy charred taste. Glad I grabbed a bottle, tenfold better than regular Guinness. I love how the aroma and taste are like two different beers. The nose is filled with dark fruits and the taste is loaded with woodsy cocoa.

11.2 oz. bottle from Total Wine, Louisville. Bottled as "Antwerpen Stout." Aroma: Moderate chocolate fudge; light dark berries; light chicory coffee; very light burning leaves. Appearance: Cola dark brown with a foamy tan head that settles into a solid cap. Flavor: Chicory and drier fudge up front; fruity aspects are very subdued; a good dose ashy bitterness towards the finish. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: Definitely tick worthy, and interesting enough to separate itself from both adulterated stouts and the market stalwarts.

330 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 9/8/2016. Pours nearly opaque dark brown/black color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, toffee, toasted dark bread, molasses, raisin, fig, and date; with lighter notes of licorice, nuttiness, smoke, tobacco, wood, herbal, and roast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt, light-moderate fruity yeast, and light earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, toffee, toasted dark bread, molasses, raisin, fig, and date; with lighter notes of licorice, nuttiness, smoke, tobacco, wood, herbal, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal hop and roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, toffee, toasted dark bread, molasses, dark fruit, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, light-moderate fruity yeast, and light earthy hop flavors; with a great roasted bitter/sweet balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Lightly drying from hop/roast bitterness as well. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready, and lightly sticky/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 8%. Overall this is an outstanding foreign stout! All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, light-moderate fruity yeast, and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV. Very rich and complex for the modest ABV as well. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle: (as Antwerpen)
Pours nearly black with a thick, chunky, dark tan head.
Dark roasty chocolate, coffee aroma.
Taste is slightly ashy bitter, coffee grounds and dark chocolate malt......some vanilla notes.
Very good.....nicely full-bodied.
Aroma of chocolate, vanilla and a little alcohol. Taste rich: burned malts: koffie, chocolate, vanilla, no trace of bitterness in aftertaste. Oily mouthfeel. Complexless but very smouth, nice stout.

Black in the glass with kind of a thin soapy head. Slightly spicy cocoa aroma with a hint of dried fruit. Dry dark chocolate flavor upfront with a hint of slightly burnt pie crust. There is an awesome aftertaste of chocolate banana that hits a bit after you swallow. Very nice! Overall, a solid brew!

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with a malty backbone. Taste is slightly boozy with a. Ice chocolate taste decent

Dark brown liquid with a lasting taller tan head. Toasted to light roasted malt with a hint of sourdough and tar. Quite sweet to start and actually quite sweet throughout. Nice lace. Light smoke and bits of acidity help balance things. Slight notes of lavender. Finish and linger have some buckwheat honey notes. Much more depth than the standard found in the States. Feel is full but there is a significant amount of effervescence. Light roasted malt, dark chocolate, and mild smoke linger. Quite enjoyable.
bottle bb 20/11/17 scura discreta schiuma media persistenza caffe tosture liquirizia filo cioccolato amaro leggero alcolico amaro no n molto intenso discreta beva

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2016 Noire à mousse beige assez persistante et bulles moyennes. Nez au café bien sûr, au chocolat, biscuit, fruits noirs. Bouche au cacao, au café, des touches de réglisse et en finale une splendide amertume qui reste longtemps longtemps.

Aroma is quite pleasant. Appearance black with a nice head that affords lacing for most of the drink time. Taste is unique and very good, slightly dry, not sweet but not bitter at all. Could be a tad thicker but that is a personal preference. I could drink this one all day. My favorite offering from Guinness to date. I do wish it was a bit thicker but that is all it lacks in my opinion.

12oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee in a Sam Smith pint glass. Surprising aromas of raisins, candied fruit, earth, old wood and vanilla. Pours a deep chocolately brown, less opaque than Guinness Draught, with a finger of dense foamy head. Generous carbonation visible percolating up from the bottom of the glass. Very slight lacing on the way down. Taste is malty and minerally up front transitioning gradually into an earthy/fruity finish. Not particularly roasty at all. Solidly medium bodied, buoyed up tremendously by extremely generous carbonation. Lightly sweet and lightly mouthcoating, but balance is very good, as expected from a Guinness brew. A novel twist on the Guinness formula, and a pleasure to drink. The flavor up front is so quick and intense Im not sure what to make of it, but Im sure having a lot of fun trying. The roastyness of Guinness Draught is gone, replaced by a very unique raisinyness that I find well balanced and enjoyable. Very happy so far with these new crafty brews Guinness has been cooking up. Slainte!

Black pour but not completely; some light passes through. Tannish foam is sturdy and long lasting.

Roasted malt, chocolate, and a milky smell.

Roasty with dark chocolate bitterness, some sweet notes, a bit of a smokey character. Booze is noticeable.

Fairly big bodied with mild carbonation.

This bears similar qualities to the John Martin version and is quite enjoyable.

0,33 l bottle. Pours dark brown with big thick lasting tan head. Aroma is caramel, roasted almost burnt malt, some coffee, chocolate and licorice. Flavor is dominated by roasty malt, espresso, caramel, maybe a hint of sourness. Taste is medium sweet, complemented by medium bitterness, creamy texture, average carbonation. Finish is long, light sweet and rather bitter. Alcohol is present, but not annoying, just enough for that warm feeling as you drink it.

NEW BEER, FIRST RATE.

Pours nearly black with a light tan head. Aroma of light cocoa, ash, some roast. Tobacco. Taste is dry with a sticky tobacco note. Cola qualities. Not bad, eh?
Delicious, strong, though slightly watery for the level of alcohol (thanks Erica)

33cl bottle at home. Appearance: dark with medium tan head. Aroma: dark malts, bread, cereal, milk and butterscotch. Taste: medium sweetness and medium bitterness. Notes of dark malts, cereal, almonds and milk. A little metallic aftertaste. Palate: medium bodied, oily texture and medium lively carbonation.

Con la riqueza que le aportan 250 años de historia, la Guinness es indisociable de Eire, excepto en esta versión también denominada GXS, y elaborada por Arthur Guinness exclusivamente para John Martin en el marco de su desarrollo en el continente europeo. Evidentemente, las particularidades del gusto son similares a las de su prima irlandesa tradicional, pero a un nivel mucho más denso, especialmente por su grado de alcohol del 8%, que hace explotar el sabor de la malta torrefactada y achicorada, sobre un amargor de madera ahumada y regaliz, dejando un retrogusto muy prolongado. Está casi desprovista de azúcares y por eso, tras una maduración de unas semanas, presenta virtudes nutritivas y naturales sanas para el organismo. Guinness is good for you, una verdad que goza de plena vigencia hoy más que nunca.
Per me rimane la migliore guinness, retrogusto complesso e speziato, densa e corposa, amaro contenuto ed equilibrato... come si fa a sottovalutare una birra come questa?

Bottle shared thanks to Deanso. Very dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel, oxidized notes, toffee and malt. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Medium bodied with big alcohol warmth in the finish and soft carbonation. [23-08-2016]

From 0,33 L bottle, pours deep black with light-brown, stable head. Aroma is full of liquorice, roast malts, dark bread, hops are also slightly recognizable. Taste is heavy malty, toasted, slightly sweet, it gets bitter in the middle with time leading to a medium bitter, quite long malty-bitter finish. Creamy, thick mouthfeel, with soft carbonation and a medium to full body. I really like it, thats how a stout has to be in my opinion, malty, roasty with a good balance between sweetness and bitterness, Its a bit thicker than the Guinness draught.

Bottle courtesy of Deanso. Poured a clear dark brown with a thin broken off white head. The aroma is sweet caramel malt. The flavour is strong liqiourice bitter with a big alcoholic liqourice bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Light toffee aroma. Big tan head and black color. Light caramel sweet and sour and roasted bitter notes. Medium body, dry finish,

330ml bottle BB 14/7/2017
Aroma is sweet roasted malt.
Poured black with ample tan head and good lacing.
Good lingering bitterness with roasted malt finish and a slight metallic note.
Not the same as Guinness on tap but still good.
Bottle, 330 ml, courtesy and shared with JFK10000. Pours black, medium tan head. Roasted, burnt, malty, chocolate. Finishes bitter. Bit warming. Medium bodied.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2017 Bottle. Aroma: sweet cherry, liquorice, sweet. Beautiful looking beer in the glass, black, beautiful brown head. Taste: sweet but also hoppy, delicious, malty and wonderfully balanced, smoked. Best Guinness I have ever had

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2017 Olhão 18/7 2016. 33 cl bottle from Oriente Modelo Supermarket. Yellow label with the characteristic harp. Declarations of "Genuine Quality" and "Special Export". Makes you wonder why beers with a high ABV is often "Export Beers"? Are the Brewers afraid that people at home will actually get drunk? So they have to send the strong beer out of the country. Pours opaque dark brown with light beige head. Head is kind of dense but settles as flimsy thin layer of foam. Moderate lacing. Aroma is sweet with chocolate, coffee, roasted dark malts and a whiff of alcohol. Some more subdued bitter notes. Soft carbonation and thick creamy palate. Flavor is intensly sweet and a bit sugary followed by light bitterness. A quite heavy fellow which would fit in nicely on a cold day in December. A bit misplaced in Portugal in 30 degrees.

Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso ricorda orzo tostato e caffè. Lintensità olfattiva è elevata e la persistenza olfattiva è apprezzabile. Il cappello è di schiuma compatta, cremosa, aderente ed ha una buona tenuta. Le bollicine sono medio-fini, con carbonazione media. Il colore è scuro impenetrabile, ma lascia intravedere il perlage costituito da bollicine fini con carbonazione persistente ed insistita. Il corpo è strutturato non pesante. Il dolce è medio e lamaro è medio. Lintensità gustativa è elevata e la persistenza gustativa è buona e lunga. Il gusto è piacevole. Le sensazioni boccali finali sono di facile beva. Il finale è setoso, amarognolo, lungo, pulito e complesso. Il retrogusto è intenso. Laroma in bocca riporta sentori di caramello, miele, cereali, caffè, pane tostato, resina, frutta secca, alcol presente non invadente.

Black colour, average head, slightly off-white, decent persistence, some lacing. Aroma has caramel malts, milk coffee and red fruits. Taste is on the sweet side with a slight hint of bitterness in the finish: buttery/milky sweetness, a light hint of roasted malts, slight red fruits, liquorice. Medium body, almost flat, decently creamy. Easy, and easily forgettable.

The beer looks perfect, like an example for every stout. The color of te beer is pitch black on the eye and a dark ruby red glow in the light. The beer is rather clear. On top of the beer there is a nice layer of rough almond colored foam. 
The smell of the beer is quite nice but a tiny bit mild. I smell some lovely biscuit-like malts, toasty and roasty. I love this roasted barley aroma. The beer has a little salty touch to it. The smell is that of the regular Guinness draught, with a bit more sweetness to it. 
The taste is nice. I taste some sweet fruity aromas and some nice roasted barley. The beer has a strong licorice taste. The roast flavor is a bit on the background in the taste. There is a nice savory touch to the beer. It is truly a lovely stout. Great.

Goryczka lekko powyżej niskiej, palona, z popiołowym, tytoniowym afterteasem, dość rzadkie w odbiorze.
FES, który przypomina Milk Stouta w aromacie i Coffee Stouta w smaku :) Bardzo sesyjny pomimo wysokiego, nieźle ukrytego alkoholu.

Roasted malts, coffee, dark brown/black, medium body, law carbonation, dried fruits, roasted malts, body is not full enough for me and there is too much alcohol in evidence...good but practically a Guinness too strong and not elegant.

21/05/2016 - 33cl bottle @ a party @ former Jeugdhuis t Stadt, Welden.
Black colour with nice light tanned head. Nose is roasted mals, some caramel. Taste is grains, coffee, some mocha, some caramel. Thin mouthfeel.

Stout pour with large lasting head. A: buttermilk, licorice note, sweet dark malts, vanilla, wood note. T: smokey note kicks in from offset. Bit oily mouthfeel. Nice and long development which starts with the sweetness from the malts, moves towards vanilla, smokey bacon, back to malts with fruity touch, mostly banana. Finish is bitter, rye, tar.

From the bottle poured into nosing glass, pours pitch black with thick beige head. Nose is intense roasted malts, some smoke and alcohol there too paired with some liquorice. Taste is roasty alcoholic, some roasted nuts. Residual alcohol is long lasting...

0.33l bottle from a sri lankan shop in bern. pours a hazy very dark chestnut with a steady beige head and a nice lacing. aroma of alcohol, toasted malts, cinnamon, caramel. flavour of alcohol, nuts, bread, bacon, slightly sour espresso. dry bitter finish. alcohol feels foreign and unnatural, as if in a beer-vodka cocktail.

Mijn lievelings stout, lekker zwart en smokerige smaak. Van een pint kan je heel lang van genieten.

Bottle at Cafe Karpershoek. Pours dark brown/black with a beige head. Aroma of smooth dark malt with a bit of hop. Flavor starts treacle. Very. This is not dry. Seems quite different from what we get in the U.S. of A.

Very dark, almost completely black. Nice thick head and it also gives nice lacing. Aroma is fresh and light. Taste is quite bitter but chocolate. Also roast and maybe a bit burned. Not bad, have a few so going to enjoy some more.

Export stout. Caramel zoet roast aroma, komt later pas echt goed los. Volle smaak, helaas te veel koolzuur, mooi gebrand droge nasmaak met mooi zacht Dublin water profiel!! Gebrand bittere, rozijn nasmaak van de mout, koffie

330ml bottle, lots of occasions. A classical.
In short: roasty dry stout.
Pours quite dark with nice tan head. Moderate head retention, some lacing. Roasty, licorice, coffee nose. Medium to full body, average to soft carbonation, oily texture. Taste is roasty, coffee, some raisins and plums, licorice. Smooth, some dry and bitter finish. Enjoyable.

Maker: St. Jamess Gate (Diageo), Dublin, Ireland ***
Beer: Guinness Special Stout (Belgian) (bottled, 330ml) ***
Style: Imperial Stout ***
ALC.VOL.: 8.0% ***

"Special version of bottled Guinness for Belgium, France, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands. Brewed in Ireland for Anthony Martin." ***

Colour: Jet black, impenetrable, with a big, frothy beige head. ***
Nose: Roasted malts, lactose, smokey bacon(!), hints of vanilla. ***
Texture: Medium to full body, oily. Modest carbonation. ***
Taste: Roasted malts, estery notes, yeast and lactose in the beginning. Smokey bacon towards the middle. Espresso. Finish is sour coffee, citrus, yeast. After taste of caramel malts, coffee. ***

Impressions: A world apart from the usual Guinness "Original Draught", this export, Imperial Stout version has much more depth and doesnt rely on charcoal exclusively for effect. Eminently (and dangerously) drinkable at 8%.

I must admit Im a bit biased by this one, as it was one of the first "good beers" I had, and has settled for me what a good foreign stout must be.
Roast barley aroma, chocolate, hints of coffee. Pitch black with smooth tan head. Taste of roast cereal, and pretty much like the aroma. Full bodied but not overwhelmingly so, drinkable. Thick.

One of the best around, in my humble opinion.

Marrone molto scura, quasi nera, con riflessi caramello, schiuma beige di media persistenza.
Aroma di liquirizia, caffè, zucchero bruciato, frutti rossi.
Al palato stesse componenti, maggiormente presenti liquirizia e tostato (caffè), finale acido con frutti rossi e ricordi di cacao, forse l'alcool si percepisce troppo.
Ben carbonata, corpo medio-leggero.

330ml bottle enjoyed @ home. Pours black with a thick beige head. Aroma is sweet with light roasted malt, lactose, liquorice, some coffee, caramel and bread. Flavour is sweet and light bitteer. Medium bodied and average carbonation. Finish is watery, blunt and bittersweet.

Lovely bitter finish. Highly drinkable and most enjoyable. Only criticism would be that its perhaps too smooth, too easy.

FTA. 33cl. There is nothing special about it. If you really miss the UK stout, and are stuck on the island - get this. Like 10 years ago there were nothing similar available in Estonia for example. Now there are 100s of alternative stouts. And If I want dry stout, I will get myself something else.

Black malt and butter aroma. Taste of dark roasted coffee and a little caramel. Heavy bitterness that fills the mouth for a long time. Okay but slightly bitter. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Konsumowane w Delirium Cafe w Brukseli z polecenia barmana. Barwa czarna, nieprzejrzysta, piana średnia. Nasycenie średnie. Aromat śliwek i rodzynek. W smaku śliwki i rodzynki, ale jakby w tle, nie biora góry nad wytrawnym smakiem piwa. Rewelacja jak dla mnie.

Black beer, medium tan head with lots of spotty lacing. Nose is sweet, like stale coffee with condensed milk plus roasty notes. Flavor is thick, almost chewy with sweet dried fruits, roast, coffee and bread. Some booze in the malty-roasty-bready finish along with fruity notes and some sourness. Interesting, does feel like a belgian taken on a Guinness.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2015 Bottle from beerexpress in Tallinn. BB 27.08.16. Pours dark, probably near black, with a light beige head with excellent retention and rather thick lacing. The nose strikes at first as strangely nostalgic, like kama with kefir - not necessarily something I have fond memories of... Its also very roasty, sourish, bready, theres molasses, coffee and cocoa. Tastes really sweet initially - even sugary, but not too much, with a lot of roastiness and finishing bitterness. Kind of robust. No carbonation to talk about... or... thats funny, as Im almost halfway through, the carbonation has become very noticeable and even crisp - go figure. Theres a somewhat irritatingly fizzy finishing mouthfeel. The hop (extract!) bitterness in the finish, together with the roastiness, make for a curious and somewhat unusual mix. Rather thin texture. Overall Id say this is a very interesting, kind of schizophrenic brew - I had it for the first time but I can see myself growing to like it. Nice!

Dark black with a thick creamy foam ,good retention. Leaves a thick and creamy mouth feel. Malt, bready, coffee, hazelnut, and dark sugar. English type stout not to be confused by the classic Guinness.

It is a typical stout or we could say maybe a kind of porter. The taste is like a sweet coffee and caramel but there is a side bitter. It is a tasty beer even the fact that guinness is a multinational. The quality is average or more, hundred times better than a heineken.

Típico color casi negro y la típica también espuma densa y manchada. En aroma hay bastantes cosas, predominando los tonos de malta tostada, café y chocolate. En boca es lo mismo, pero rodeado de un buen amargor. También hay tonos dulces, aunque por encima de todo la rica malta tostada. Bastante más cuerpo que la normal, lo que la hace mucho más sabrosa y disfrutable, aunque menos bebible. Su otro logro es que el alcohol queda bastante bien escondido

Bottle. Dark body, medium beige head. Aroma has rich roast with hints of high roast coffee. Sweet yet also a bit astringent roast in taste. Sweet cream coffee flavour with side tastes of dry cocoa powder and licorice. Resembles some Imperial Stouts but the body is not heavy and oily - its drinkable like a beer should be. Good one. In my world, people would boycott the regular watery Guinness Draught and demand it to be replaced with this one.

330ml bottle. Very dark brown color. Huge size, thick and creamy tan head, stays. Roast, caramel, sweet, tiny bit of molasses in aroma. Nice roasted malts, candy caramel, sweet in taste. Long lasting sweet, almost ashy, roasted malts in aftertaste. Roast bitterness on tongue. Nice brew!

800th rating and one if the last missing styles in my list. Black color with big tan head. Roasted malts, a bit metallic (not irritating though), some fruitiness, can?t quite tell which one. Taste is roasted malts, some fruits again, burnt. Some chocolate. Dry finish. Low carbonation, feels a bit buttery. Full-bodied and dry at the same time. This has much more flavour than the classic Guinness, but the drinkability suffers a bit.

0,33L bottle (from beerExpress, Tallinn). Pours dark brown-black with light brown head. The head stays for some time. Aroma is salty, metallic, roast, malt. Flavor is sweet, bitter, roast, metallic, buttery, with licorice and burnt notes. Finish is roast-malt bitter and has some alcohol. Overall: solid brew. A lot better than the regular Guinness we get here.
Guinness as it should be. Rich chocolate, dark roast, bitter... Slight copper very nice ones

Bottle back at the room. I love that Belgium has its own Guinness. Must be the only European foreign export. Pours Black with a Beige head. Advanced charred malty sweetness on the nose. Lots of roasted malt character but with fruity sweetness and a hit of booze. Chocolatey charred bitterness. Theres a lot going on. Im a big fan of the non-traditional Guinnesses. This is probably my favourite.

Tiefschwarz mit recht beständigem hellbraunem Schaum. Geruch: Tolle Aromen von Röstmalz, Karamell, getrocknete Früchte. Sehr einladend! Geschmacklich beginnt das Bier mit einer leichten Süße und einer Aromenvielfalt von stark geröstetem Malz, Kaffee, Schokolade, Rauch. Sehr komplex! Dazu gesellt sich eine leichte Bitterkeit, die einen langen Abklang einleitet. Dazu eine wunderbar passende ölige Textur.

Empfehlung!

Aroma: roasted smoked notes, coffee, dried fruits.
Appearance: dark color, nice creamy head.
Taste: acid and smoked, roasted dark malts, dried fruits, bitter chocolate, coffee, semi-dry, bonfire.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, ashy rosted finish.
Overall: Really good stuff, nice smoked notes and deep compex taste.

Aroma: toasted malts, coffee, chocolate, alcohol. Appearance: black, medium, creamy, beige head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: bitters intensify, yet some sweetness as well, intense toasted malts, chocolate, dry cacao, coffee, dry finish. Overall: nice Foreign Stout - is this really any better than the other Guinness FE, cant really tell. Bottle from Utobeer, London Bridge.

33 cl bottle @ home. Pours a dark brown, almost black beer and brown head. Strong aroma, roasted malt, chocolate, brown sugar, coffee, mokka and some dark fruits. Taste starts off sweet, followed by bitterness and some sourness. Palate is too lively, should be more creamy.

330ml bottle. Pours black with generous off-white head. Taste is rich and smooth with a nice sweetness ahead of bitter roasted malts. Hardly recognisable as Guinness, beefed up with flavour and infinitely more drinkable. This is Guinness brewed to its full potential.

Bottle. Black body, creamy light brown head. Aroma of coffee, Hazelnut, chocolate. Malt heavy taste , elements of roast and cocoa. Soft bitter finish. A bit more of everything compared to the regular G

Rich and complex.

Keg at Delirium. It pours jet black with a decent tan head. The nose is rich roast, molasses, liquorice, earthy, maltesers and chocolate. The taste is rich roast, bitter-sweet, molasses, earthy, chocolate malt, maltesers, toasty, light alcohol, chocolate ice-cream and liquorice with a small tan head. Medium+ body and fine carbonation. Nice bitter-sweet balance to it. A solid beverage for sure.
Dark beer with brown head. Creamy beer, great texture, with some caramel and toffee. And lots of dark chocolate! Some sweetness from some dark fruits. Full bodied. Great beer.

Beer dark as night in a creamy liquid. The cream is light caramel, huge, foamy, stable with fine bubbles that emerge forming a beautiful thin foam. Formed ties on the walls of glass along the tasting.

The Aroma initially shows weak but with good grades of roasted malts and will slowly growing with soft notes of coffee, dark chocolate, raisins, dark cherries, prunes, and a light acidity an unpleasant little.

Taste brings a fruity sweetness of raisins, plums, lots of coffee, slightly bitter chocolate and tar noticeable generating a barely perceptible bitterness, but ending the sip an average bitterness. The finish is slightly alcoholic, but good insertion in the set and the hops are practically imperceptible.

The Aftertaste is faintly smoked. Again it is perceived alcohol that brings a certain dryness, but nothing that brings imbalance to the set.

Medium Body Full, oily and creamy texture and an average constant carbonation.
Good and Interesting Porter. Clearly the best Guinness variant Ive ever tasted. Very tasty and good to drink. Excellent drinkability.

Recommend!

0,33 l bottle from EDEKA Mohr, bottled on 11/12/2014. Clear, very dark red to black with a huge, foamy, stable, tan head. Great aroma of raisins, prunes, coffee, dark chocolate and toffee, a bit of tar as well. Wow! Different aromas come to the front every time you smell it. Sweetish taste of raisins, prunes, dark cherries, lots of coffee, dark chocolate and hints of tar. Short, slightly bitter and minimally sourish, gently alcoholic finish. Medium to full body, oily and creamy texture, flat carbonation. What a gem! Very complex, so many different and strong flavours, a satisfying finish, but also very well balanced. Moreish!

Has the traditional tar and roast coffee from the guinness malt but with the extra alcohol comes more sweetness to make this something closer to an imperial stout. From a bottle its unfortunately impossible to get a pour that matches a good pub though.

33cl bottle. Black stout with lovely brown, firm head. A beautiful beer, with a great scent. Some vanilla, even coconut, and of course the coffee hints. The bitterness tops the ending. Different from a draught stout, but definitely as nice! Great to drink ice cold.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2015 33 cl, flaske, 8.0 % ABV, BB 18/06/16, købt i African House i Abel Cathrinesgade 3 på Vesterbro i København, 23. marts 2015. Sort olie-Porter, omend tyndere konsistens, under ophældning. Skumtoppen er ganske stor og brun/moccafarvet, 5 cm. Fine bobler, som svinder til et fint skumlandskab og ned til 1-2 cm tykkelse. I det hele taget en fin åbning. Aromaen er i starten lidt svag og mest præget af ristet malt. Senere er den mere præget af kaffe, frugt og ubehagelig syre. Frugtaromaen, som både er sød og syrlig, kan godt være jordbær, og der er er desuden noter af metal. Smagen indledes let syrlig og frugtrig, og ellers er indtrykket bittert og præget af en brændt smag af de ristede malte. En let sødme, en medium bitterhed og, som nævnt, en let syrlighed. Øllets krop er mellem fyldig med en medium karbonering. Konsistensen er olieret. God og tydelig Porter og klart den bedste Guiness-variant, jeg har smagt. Ganske velsmagende og fin at drikke.
Uhm den smager godt. Det starter med en suveræn stout-duft. Lækkert. Smagen som vi kender Guinness. Nice. Måske lige en anelse for sød/tyk for min smag. Skyldes nok det er Belgian version!

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 Bottle. Big brownish head very persistent. Very dark brown, black in fact. Aroma is dark fruits, prune and caramel. Flavor is roasted and burnt malts, cocoa, plum, liquorice, burnt sugar with some alcohol presence. Long aftertSte. A very good foreign stout!

Bottle, pours black with a tan head. Nose: chocolate, dark fruit, caramelTaste: chocolate, roast, caramel, liquorice. Miedium-high sweet, medium bitterness, full body,creamy texture, soft carbonation. Long bittersweet chocolate finish. Lovely stout, which is a bit like a belgian strong ale.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2017 Strong Guinness made for the Belgian market under license of Anthony Martin; if export stout is to be seen as a separate substyle, different from e.g. foreign stout and others, then this must be the archetypical example, though it is admittedly hard to maintain the concept as a separate style in the modern craft beer era - it only made sense in the traditional context of 19th and 20th century Europe.  Black (though translucent mahogany on the edges) with a beige, dense head, dense aroma of roasted coffee beans, iron, dried fruits, molasses, pepper. Spicy drop taste with bitter chocolate and black coffee, uncompromizing roasted bitterness, thick and mouth-filling, assertive and even a bit salty, very dry with a long bitter finish, oily mouthfeel. Very enjoyable, but seems to have turned sweeter and more caramelly malty in recent years, I miss the black roastedness it had in the old days.  My rating here is therefore an average of both.

Review based on BJCP2008 guidelines (style 13D). Bottle 33 cl - Batch L4120. AROMA: sweet and vinous alcoholic like aroma with roasted and coffee notes. some dry grapes aromas. low non existent hop aromas. no diacetyl. APPEARANCE: deep brown color and opaque. nice large and moussy tanned head with good retention. TASTE: roasted grains dominate with some coffee and cacao notes. medium-high bitterness that lingers into the aftertaste with very low to none hop flavours. alcohol notes present with very low diacetyl. finishes somewhat dry. PALATE: médium body with a velvety like texture. some warming impression present. moderate carbonation. OVERALL: a nice export stout with very pronounced roasted flavour, velvety texture and a bit on the dry side.

La longueur enchaîne avec de grandes beautés, des saveurs vraiment riches, denses et pourtant
douces. Très bel amalgame et harmonie fantastique.
La levure est parfaitement incluse.
Lalcool est bien progressif, et on sent leffet bienheureux des 3,8 % abv en plus que la classique : effet sur les saveurs et la suavité.
La finale ne faiblit pas et témoigne de ce quest un grand stout.
CONCLUSION : quel bonheur de trouver LA vraie version de lIrlande dans LA version belge de sa
bière emblématique, 
comme quoi les Irlandais ont parfaitement compris que le belge était exigeant sur la vérité 
dune bière, son aspect équilibré et dense, avec une force de caractère intégrale.
Merci Guinness pour ce bel hommage à la Belgique.

Flaske kjøpt på African House, Vesterbro (!) og delt med Ovesen: højt belgisk skum som varer og varer. Tørr aroma med kaffe, lær og sjokolade. En eksemplarisk stout.

Color very dark brown. Aroma dark chocolate, hops. Taste alcohol, bitter, hops. Palate lasting bitter. Overall maybe I like the original better.
I like this beer, because the taste is very very good! The aroma is strange, but tasty at the same time!

Oh the sought after Belgian Guinness, for some reason I was under the impression that this wasnt even common in Belgium... alas it was in every bottle shop, night shop, and grocery store we went to. 

Pours a very dark, almost black color with some ruby hues when held up to the light.. The head is small but it leaves a nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is roasty and a bit buttery at first, but that butteriness fades off. The aroma has some interesting notes of over ripe fruit that becomes more focused and cherry like as the beer starts to open up.  

The flavor is roasty and nicely bitter. All around well rounded with a mild sweetness, the finish is dry and a little bit hot. Some pear and cherry are weird but not unwelcome alongside the bold espresso like coffee tones.  

What a strange beer, certainly worth a try for anyone curious.

Bottle from Makro, Thessaloniki: Black colour with medium sized tan head. Aromas of caramel, coffee and roasted malts. Light bitter taste with caramel and coffee. Full body wit average carbonation. Overall, the best Guinness beer.

33 cL bottle into a Guinness goblet at Sheffield Tap.  Black with a bubbly head yellow/brown head.  Dry stout, a bit portery.  Roasted but still moist.  Metallic and stout aroma.  A hint of treacle sweetness and alcohol over and above the normal Guinness taste.  Good.

Aroma: Toffee, milk chocolate, lots of caramel, smoke, soil, nuts...

Mouthfeel: Full and creamy.

Taste: Firm, malty, smokey, roast flavour. Exceptionaly delicious.

Finish: Alcohol, potent coffee-like bitterness.

Overall: Near perfect. Very rich, easily drinkable.

330ml bottle. Opaque black with huge firm creamy lacing tan head. Fruity aroma like dark berries with decent dark malty and roasty addenda, a salty touch. Dry dark malty taste, slightly roasty, increasingly dry and roasty toward the finish, a salty note. Lasting dry and roasty finish.

Gut haltende Schaumkrone nicht so gut wie beim Draught, dennoch beachtlich, Farbe schwarz. Natürlich ist es wieder schön Geschmacksintensiv etwas nach lakritz, röstmalzig-Kaffee, aber auch Alkohol der sich aber gut einfügt. Im Nachgeschmack ist der Alkohol etwas stärker, aber auch nicht zu aufdringlich, ausserdem etwas Kaffee-bitter. Gut!
Test vom 12.4.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 13,12,12,13,12,12 - 12,25
Black with a red edge, large fluffy beige head. Salty roasted liquorice aroma, with some dry, earthy gunpowder notes. Medium bodied. Semi dry, medium bitterness.

Bottle.

Black with a small head. The aroma was rather weak with some notes of roasted malt, bread and some smoke. The taste was dry and a bit better than the aroma. Medium body.

Lite tjock pastilldoft. Smaken är ganska rökig, mycket kaffe som gör den mycket torr. Fin fyllighet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

dry natural smoky woody bitter coffee, bitter chocolate. great body yet silky.  middeep yet drinkable. Not really heavy just when I try to drink too quickly i feel the alc taste too dominate.
 so its tellin ya to relax

Falls apart towards the mid to end with just alcohol mixed with regular G sensations and taste... just more roasty. A tab bit disappointed yet very pleased at same time. Has a nice wow factor to begin with. Will have to try again.

A blend of malt, smoke, bitterness, licorice, coffee. Nothing stands out in this drink and thats what I like about it. Great body and nothing overpowering. In my opinion this is greater than foreign extra Ireland or Nigeria.
Fijne koffie aroma, met rijp donker fruit. Smaak is koffie, chocola, wat rozijnen en soja saus (?). Nasmaak is bitter. Traditionele Guinness kraag.

33cl bottle from Kihoskh. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and smoke (reminds me of bonfire). I guess the notes of smoked wood comes from the roasted malt, anyway - its quite nice. Quite sweet, but well balanced with a subtle bitterness. Smooth and creamy with a mideum body. Easy to drink, and the alcohol is very well integrated. The smokey aroma was the biggest surprise for me, I did not remember that - just that I liked it. It is still a quite nice stout, although a bit to sweet. Clearly one of the best from St. Jamess Gate.

330 ml bottle. Pours very dark brown. Generous dark tan head. Quite carbonated. Head disappears slowly. Aroma of sweet alcohol and malt. Taste of sugary malt. Sweetness continues...then gives way to burnt caramel flavours.

This was a live review: I am in my hotel room on the Belgian coast. The wife is dead on her feet, so we stopped at a Night Store for me to have a night-cap beer. The only beer they sold that I hadnt reviewed was this one. Cant believe Im reviewing an Irish beer in Belgium!

33cl Brown bottle, best before 29 Jan 2012, reviewed in Middelkerke on 26 May 2011.

Poured into a glass tumbler, because that is what was available in the hotel room.

Its a Guinness, so its dark with a huge tanned head: the smell is of a regular Guinness with alcohol added. Even the head (which refuses to shrink) tastes like an alcoholic infused normal Guinness.

Dry and malty taste, the alcohol detected in the aroma is hidden better within the mouth flavours, but appears somewhat in the aftertaste as the mouth drys; and as already mentioned, in the foaming head.

Not as well balanced as I expected and not a beer Id search for, certainly not in Belgium: where there are so many great beers to try.

Black with a faint red tint and thick tan frothy carbonation, that somewhat lasts. Smells of brown suger, roast and caramel malt. Faint smell. Full creamy oily body with soft carbonation. Sweet start with a dry smokey finish that lingers . Some coffee roast that a bit strong. Leaves my mouth feeling a bit shot, burnt and ashy. Its missing the sweet butter chocolate of the Foreign Extra Stout. Too smokey roast.
Dark colour and generous head. Chocolate, coffee, and even some notes resembling wine (subtle). More sweetness than expected overall, its not bad though.

Bottle 33cl.
Aroma of coffee and chocolate, roasted.
Very dark color with a light brown head lasting quite long.
The sweet roasted taste changes pretty soon into a more bitter one.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and its not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog!

Im Glas ist es absolut tiefschwarz, mit einer schönen, Guinnesstypischen feinen Cremekrone. Es riecht süßlich malzig. Beim Blindtest würde ich hier absolut auf einen Belgier tippen. Der Antrunk ist sehr röstmalzig und alkoholisch, der Abgang hallt sehr lange nach, und zwar kaffeeartig und ebenfalls alkoholisch. Im Laufe kommt ein leicht herbes Aroma hinzu, welches sich aber kaum gegen die stark röstmalzige und alkoholische Note behaupten kann. Ganz im Gegensatz zu der Karamell-artigen Note, welche ab der Mitte auftaucht und sich bis zum Ende behaupten kann. Trinkt sich insgesamt doch sehr schwerfällig. Sollte man mal probiert haben, muss man aber nicht unbedingt wieder haben. Da gibts bessere Kollegen, die wesentlich angenehmer zu trinken sind!

33cl bottle, 8%, 1.90. Very dark brown, almost black beer with a massive rocky tanned head, lasting. Nose of toasted cereals and chocolate. Aroma is as expected, roasted malts allover, coffee and dark chocolate. Has some sweetness in the beginning but become strongly bitter instantly. Intense bitter finish. Texture is creamy to oily, body medium to full, average carbonation. Its quite sharp but nice product.

Bottle. Rich aroma of coffee, chocolate and fainter of licorice, pours a strong, brown head with dark brown appearance. Quite sweet with very good bitterness with roasted coffee notes. My first foreign stout, enjoyed the sweetness, impressed and suited me well.

Bottle at Il Bar Sotto Il Mare.  Dark brown/black pour with a tan head.  Dark roasted malt aromas with just a hint of licorice.  Nice thicker body with good carbonation.  Bitter up from with a nice roasty middle and semi sweet finish.  Lots of dark roasted malts, toffee, bitter cacao and hint of licorice.  Very impressed by this beer.

33 cl. bottle @ home. Dark brown with a tan head. Coffee and chocolate in the aroma. A lot more flavourful than the draught version. I found that one a dissapointment and this one a very enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 chocolate, coffee, herbs, leather, smoke, vanilla, skunky, ginger, licorice, alcohol, black, brown foam, rocky head, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, umami, medium body, sticky, bitter, lively,

33 cl bottle. Black colour with big Brown head. Aromas of cold coffee and hutjes malts. Flavour is coffee and chocolate, burned malts and some biggetjes. Finish is smokey with some bay leaf. Oily mouthfeel, medium body.
Not my favourite beerstyle.

Bottle. Slightly bitter roasted brain aromaPours dark brown to black with a big creamy lacing golden brown head. Demera sugar, caramel and roasted barley, herbal hops. Roast and chocolate aftertaste. Full, slightly sticky on the palate, delicate carbonation prevents it from being cloying.
Dark, near black with brown head. Theres roasted matls and some hoppy bitterness, along with some undefinable sweetness (maybe toffee). Nice stout, but not as good as most impies.

From backlog 
Head: espresso, creamy , small 
Colour: black 
Smell: roastyness, malts, chocolat, cold coffee, bitter cocoa 
Taste: nice balance between the coffee and chocolat bitterness and the bitter/sweetness of the roasted malts, dry end , earhty after , not bad !

Pours black with a brown head that sticks to the glass.
Aroma is coffee, burned malts, maybe some cocoa
Roast coffee taste, some bitter notes. Dry aftertaste, mocha and roastyness. Some chocolatty notes
Definitely better than the draught version.
(expire date was february 2004)

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Bijna zwart van kleur met veel kraag bij het inschenken, ziet er goed uit. Ruikt en smaakt erg moutig en caramellig. Bitterzoet met een lange rokerige  nasmaak. Lekker bier om rustig te drinken.
Chocolate and caramel on the nose.   It pours black with a think white head. Bittersweet dark chocolate upfront  with caramel malts and toasted bread following    Very clean crisp finish, refreshing
Botle from el corte ingles, lisbon. Thick light brown head and thick texture. Dark dense color. Low carbonation. Medium to high bitterness. Coffee/chocolate/roasted aroma.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 (Bottled) Nothing too different about this to the other GF/Stout in recipe -other than more booze . When ive sampled the other Guinness  exports (dublin,nigeria) im struck by the difference in quality to the usual soulless draught guinness on reflection . Im also left happy enough ,as its a  pretty sippable and easy texture on offer ,its oily roasty richness is freindly -united with an 8% that is warming .   This rests  black with a beige ring that dies soon...oaky ,rich roasty ,buttery nose .   rich  notes linger -suggesting  dark fruit (raisins) winey and oily , a dry roast finish gives a dark chocolate bitterness .  A nice robust Guinnes equivalent -with decent complexity.

Pours completely black with a small head. Heavy coffee, malt, brown sugar aroma. Beautiful taste of roast coffee with a refreshing hint of sourness. Velvet mouthfeel. Excellent beer - the only problem is youll want one of these whenever you try the watery standard Guinness.

33cl bottle. Dark black with a big cappuccino head. Nose : Toffee, caramel and cheese. Tiramisu flavors.  Sip : Oily with a very little but still present  micro-biting from carbonation liquid. Sweet caramel and coffee. Toffee. Its like you ware eating "cheetos and drinking brown beer. Funny. Once again nose said it all. Bitter coffee taste on the end. Nice. I forgot all the other Guinness I tried before. I cant wait to compare them to this one. Thanks god it has some fair amount of alcohol in it.

Bottle from Alko.  Dark, opaque cola brown beer with off-white head. Very malty aroma, caramel and roasty malts, dark chocolate, coffee, licorice on the nose. Taste is the same things with slight smokiness. Full bodied treat with nice balance.

Aroma: Loads of coffee, hint of chocolate, very roasty, maybe a bit smokey, albeit very faint. Lovely! 
Appearance: Pitch black, bit of co2 in the head, when fully poured big head which dissapeaars quickly.

Quite bitter, with sweet notes. Lovely tastes, bitter-sweet roasty, fantastic but quite on the bitter side!

Full body with tingling of the fizzly carbonation. Quite oily, finish is reasonable long, not to long not shortly. Roasted taste stays long though.

Overal, one of the more serious stouts. Quite bitter and serious roasted, Nothing like the regular Guinness. Very good beer, very good stout.
For some fascinating additional information on Guinness Special Export  see Special Guinness and Malaysian Chops Go to www.Zythumanthology.co.uk and click on the image...

Tasted in June 2011 from a 330mL bottle sent to me as an extra in a trade.  Pours opaque black with a thick tan head that leaves spotty lace after a slow recession, leaving a bit of residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is molasses, burnt brown sugar, raisin, fig, prune, and fruity yeast.  The flavor is molasses with burnt brown sugar, dried fruits, and lightly bitter dark chocolate and coffee.  The body is medium with full, creamy carbonation, and a long lightly bitter, fruity, and roasted coffee finish.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2013 0.33l bottle from CrackedKettle. This one pours pretty darn close to a black body with a nice light creamy strongly tanned head. Aroma is quite sweet with some roasted malts, vanilla-chocolate, some thin coffee and lots of caramel! Not your average Guinness this no... It has a really creamy and oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation and its medium to full-bodied. Good roasted flavors, lots of that sweet caramel, a really different and exciting flavor that I have a hard time figuring out what is. Almost like its some flowers mixed with dry cardboard (in a good way) I know I have tasted this is another stout, but just cant figure out what it is (reminds me a bit of Midtfyns Stout). Really smooth and it finishes off light warming and it ends with a long lasting coffee and slightly sweet chocolate aftertaste. Soooo much better than the dry nitro stout. 8-4-8-4-17


Shared 0.33l bottle @ Hotel room in Amsterdam with Inbreak. Pre borefts breakfast. Lovely looking massive and Lingering creamy brown head thats leaving some egregious lacings down the glass as it slowly fades. Smells of both chocolate and light burned malts. A faint creamy lactic acidity is also noted here, but I like this aroma. Its thick and really oily in the mouth but it lacks some carbonation. Whats there is almost completely gone as the head has settled. Creamy nesquick, lots of chocolate and roasted notes. So much better than the thin regulare version. Solid! 27.09.2013

Bottled 0.33L. Soft malty nose with some hints of mocca. Large creamy brownish head. Dark black reddish colour. Malty and roasty slightly bitter taste. Not very sour. At the en hoppy bitterness. A velvety fullfilled fine stout.
Pours a nice black glass with brown foam. The heavy taste of coffee and bitter black chocolate in combination with the 8% make this a very strong and very tasteful beer. Has a nice bitter aftertaste,

Bottle.
Black with a large, creamy light brown head.
Aroma: roasted, milk chocolate, some kind of candy.
Taste: licorice, chocolate, candy, pretty sweet, roasted, burnt sugar/caramel.
Medium-bodied, medium high carbonation, quite smooth.
Pretty nice, but for some reason I get a bit tired of it towards the end of the bottle.
Almost black with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 090711

Maybe its an insult to guinness lovers, but I liked this beer a lot better than the original. The alcoholpercentage and carbonation give this beer a good body. Taste is ok, smell and appearance not bad.
Bottle from Alko. Originally rated on 27.2.2010. Tasty, well balanced stout. Slightly sweet and slick mouthfeel. Nice roasty finish.

330 ml bottle. Rated @ 16.2.2010.
Pours a black colour with a large beige head. Aroma of dried fruits, chocolate and some smoked wood. Flavour of dark berries, dried fruits, chocolate, smoked wood, roasted malts and a decent amount of hops. Smooth mouthfeel with a roasty, bitter finish. Very tasty and goes well with meat.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a black beer with a beautiful big light brown head. Strong flavours of tar and black chocolate. Extremly smooth mouthfeel. Very drinkable. Some alcohol presence. Roasted malt taste. Black chocolate, roasted finish. A good foreign stout with plenty of character.

I liked this one a bit better than the regular guinness. This version has a bit more taste to it (chocolate, roasted malts, coffee). Still not my favorite. Mouthfeel is way better. Less watery and more alive.

Schwer alkoholisch liegt das Bier im Mund, erst im Mittelteil wird es süffiger, natürlich schmeckt es röstmalzig, besonders im Nachgeschmack kommt dieses Aroma stark zum Vorschein und behauptet seine Stellung. Ein bitteres Aroma ist von Anfang - Ende schmeckbar, er ereicht seinen Höhepunkt im Mittelteil und flacht (zum Glück) danach wieder auf Normalniveau ab. Süffig ist das Bier sicher nicht und auch die Aromen sind gewöhnungsbedürftig und recht stark. Wir wohl nicht vielen schmecken. 	 
Test vom 12.1.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,7,6,7,12,7 - 7,50

A nice lively hiss from the bottle when I opened it. A light mocha head leapt into the glass and the body was black with ruby flecks at the base of the glass. Aromas of buttered toast, fresh coffee, mushroom soup and indeed, powdered mushroom stock. Other notes of chocolate mousse shine through. Im going to put my neck out and say that this maybe one of my favourite smells because it couples with it great anticipation.
While it isnt the most sophisticated palate, it is tasty. It does what it says on the bottle (which is Guinness). It is refined and robust at the same time. Coffee at the fore as well as chocolate. Silky smooth and gorgeous. If I was only allowed to drink one beer for the rest of my life this would be in the top five in my pea brain as I attempt to prevaricate and beg not to be confined so. This is all that is sexy about Guinness.

Bottle. Very dark with a thin layer of foam. Aromas of caramel and rolled oats. Some ash and creamyness as well. Taste is somewhat bitter. Some caramel and toasted barley. Body is very creamy. Fairly long bitter aftertaste. Much better than the standard version here.

Hmm, I almost rated this one too low, because I compared it to the draught Guinness, rather than judging it in its own right. But lets see.. Nice dark brown colour with an creamy, tan head. Aroma close to draught Guinness, but not exactly the same. Coffee, Chicory, nuts, more of an alcohol twang. Flavour too, perhaps a bit more body. Roasted malts, chicory coffee, milk chocolate and hazelnut. Not quite as creamy as the draught Guinness, and maybe a bit light compared to other stouts, but nice in its own right. (From 33cL bottle)

Bottle.Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head.Aroma caramel, apples, dusty malt and roasted malt.Flavor is sweet and roasted with some warmth and caramel notes.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice stout.

hum, quelle belle bière, la mousse crémeuse, la couleur foncée et brune, le gout tellement typiquement guinness alors que ce nest pas la version habituelle, pourtant ca rappelle vraiment la vraie recette avec bien plus de corps, a 8 %, tout est rond, notes de café grillé, noix-noisettes grillées, amertume légère, notes de thé puerh un pue fumé, lastringence umami qui rafraichit. Pourquoi jen ai jamais bu avant?
Pitch black body with a big light brown head. Strong sweet malty aroma of caramel, toast and coffee. Lightly carbonated palate, flavour is sweet with caramel and brown sugar. Very nice.

Bottle - 330ml. Black body with a thick beige foamy/creamy head. Rich, well balanced malty aroma with hoppy, plummy, and cocoa hints. Sharp, strong malty/hoppy taste with woody, cocoa, and anise notes. Ends with a long, warming bittersweet finish. Very good!

330ml bottle.  Pours pitch black with a large tight head.  Aroma is blackberries, peat and some roasted malt.  Taste starts with some roast malt, blackberry finish and a peaty aftertaste.  Lovely beer.

Bottle thanks to drabmuh. Served in a Bruery tulip.

Pours with a thin tan head and a nearly-black body. There are some light spots of lacing around the sides and bubbles on top. The nose is light roast and a surprising amount of caramel and, especially, toffee character. Theres some light candy and brown sugar as well.

The taste brings a good dose of toffee along with some light roasted character and some super mild espresso following through after that. Medium body with moderate carbonation. The finish is fairly smooth and slightly dry. This is nice and easy to drink. The finish seems to dry out even more as I get through the bottle. Pretty good stuff. Thanks again, Matt.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-16-2010
